subclause.title: SubClause
subclause.p: Buildings with an effective height of more than 12 m or with more than 3 below ground storeys must be provided with stairway identification signs, floor level identification signs and sole-occupancy unit indicator signs in accordance with (2) to (6).

ol.xt:author: Patrick Kerrigan
ol.li: be located external to the exit on or adjacent to all doors that provide access into required fire-isolated stairway, including discharge doors; and
identify the floor levels served where the required fire-isolated stairway does not serve all floor levels; and

state—
“Stair”, or in the case of a scissor stair “Scissor Stair”, and
a unique stair descriptor; and

use text that—
is not less than 50 mm high; and
contrasts with its background; and
is legible in low level lighting conditions or when illuminated with a torch.

ol.xt:author: Patrick Kerrigan
ol.li:
be located—
at every landing that is located at a floor level and is in a required fire-isolated stairway; and
at every corridor or lobby into which an emergency lift or lift with a stretcher facility opens; and
be visible from the top step of the flight serving the relevant floor and, where possible, from inside the relevant lift where the lift car door open; and
be mounted between 1.7 m and 2 m above floor level and, as far as practicable, at the same height; and
where within a required fire-isolated stairway, identify that required exit stairway in accordance with (2)(c); and

state—
“Ground Floor” when identifying the ground floor level; or
“Level”, or in the case of a basement level “Basement”, in conjunction with a floor level descriptor; and

use text that—
is not less than 50 mm high, except the height of the character that designates the floor level descriptor must be at least 100 mm high; and
contrasts with the background, and
is legible in low level conditions or when illuminated with a torch.

subclause.title: SubClause
subclause.p: The floor level descriptor required by (3)(e)(ii) must—

ol.xt:author: Patrick Kerrigan
ol.li: for floor level above the ground floor, be numbered sequentially beginning with”1”, and
for basement levels below the ground floor, be numbered sequentially beginning with “1”.

subclause.title: SubClause
subclause.p: Where a storey in a Class 2 or Class 3 building contains more than one sole-occupancy unit, sole-occupancy unit indicator signs must be provided that state the direction to sole-occupancy units accessed on that storey.

subclause.title: SubClause
subclause.p: Sole-occupancy unit identification signs required by (5) must—

ol.xt:author: Patrick Kerrigan
ol.li: be located immediately below floor identification signs provided under (3)(a), such that the top edge of the sign is not more than 50 mm below the bottom edge of the floor identification sign; and

state—
“Units” or another suitable descriptor such as “Rooms” or “Apartments”; and
a sequential descriptor of the range of sole-occupancy units in each direction relative to the location of the sign; and
the direction in which the range of sole-occupancy units are relative to the location of the sign, such as by an arrow symbol; and

use text and symbols that—
are not less than 25 mm high; and
contrast with the background; and
are legible in low level lighting conditions or when illuminated with a torch.

ol.xt:author: Patrick Kerrigan
ol.li: Where a sole-occupancy unit is accessed from 2 or more storeys, the sole-occupancy unit need only be identified by a sole-occupancy unit identification sign on the primary access storey.
Stairway, floor level and sole-occupancy unit designations are to be consistent with designations used in block plans and other fire safety system documentation.

Notwithstanding D3D31(3)(e) and D3D31(4)—
abbreviations (such as ‘G’ for ‘Ground Floor’) may be used; and
the ground level may be identified as ‘Level 1’; and
mezzanines, split levels (such as lower ground and upper ground) and the like may be identified accordingly.

callout.xt:author: Patrick Kerrigan
callout.p: Each required fire-isolated stairway and floor level is to be provided with a unique descriptor to assist co-ordination of egress and fire brigade activities. For example, a building may be provided with 2 required fire-isolated stairways, A and B. Stairway identification signs and floor identification signs for stairway B must contain the text “Stair B”.
